369608312955731968;"Bryan_Beus#6442";"11-Oct-18 12:31 PM";"In the marketing meeting today
column2: we were trying to create a narrative to visualize what our customers will be doing with CC.

column1: There were a few areas where we ran to the edge of my understanding.
Can one of the devs please help correct this visualization wherever it is inaccurate?
Let's say that I'm a dApp dev and I want to make a card game.
I have my main asset chain. It serves as the underlying currency for performing transactions on the chain. It is not designed to be a high-market cap coin
column2: by itself.

column1: First
column2: a user will install my software
column4: do a `faucetget` cc command to get just a small amount of my base currency.

column1: With that
column2: they will then perform a transaction on the network that broadcasts their chosen pubkey (and base58 address)
column3: and also the CC-address pairing for that pubkey. This is `AddressA-on-MY-asset-chain`.

column1: For the player to really get started
column2: they first need to pay me
column3: so they can enter my ecosystem
column4: and for that we uses MoMoM and a CC-based STABLE coin. For players to pay me
column5: and to enter my gaming community
column6: I require that they send me $10 USD worth of a KMD-based STABLE coin. They'll send this from a transparent address

column1: Using MoMoM
column2: my blockchain can detect that my address on the STABLE coin received the correct amount. One of my nodes will then automatically send to `AddressA-on-MY-asset-chain`a starter kit.";"";"";

column1: 369608312955731968;"Bryan_Beus#6442";"11-Oct-18 12:31 PM";"The starter kit will include X amount of the asset chain currency.
It will also an assortment of tokens. The tokens are like cards in a character
column2: RPG-based card game.

column1: Each token has a set of descriptions and properties
column2: like STRENGTH
column6: that affect the token's ability to play against other players.

column1: Now
column2: my user wants to start playing against other players online.

column1: He and another player connect to one of my nodes
column2: and they also connect to each other. My node is acting as an Oracle.

column1: The two players place certain items into a CC-based smart contract (yet to be written?)
column2: where the person who wins will receive these items.

column1: Now
column2: they play the card game
column3: broadcasting the data of their decisions to each other. My node simply observes and records the information into my asset chain

column1: The game lasts for one hour. During that time
column2: several notarizations of my data make it into KMD

column1: 369608312955731968;"Bryan_Beus#6442";"11-Oct-18 12:33 PM";"At the conclusion of the game
column2: all three of the nodes (mine
column3: and both of the playing users)
column4: calculate the results and payout the CC smart contract according to the winner.

column1: The player who won now has a collection of new tokens that they can use to play again
column2: while the other player has to start over (and perhaps the payout of items is varied across the game

column1: 369608312955731968;"Bryan_Beus#6442";"11-Oct-18 12:36 PM";"Out of the technologies above
column2: dPoW is working fairly reliably
column3: MoMoM is online but not thoroughly tested yet
column7: and there is a CC smart contract required to manage the payout according to the results.

column1: Those are the aspects that KMD and the open-source KMD-ecosystem community want to provide to our users.
In addition
column2: the dApp developer will want to write their own unique software to make a beautiful dApp game.

column1: How are we doing in understanding?";"";"";
232679450301431808;"blackjok3r#3181";"11-Oct-18 12:37 PM";"Thats a very large scope... and kind of similar to something me and a mate discussed a while back.";"";"";

column2: ie number of chains.";"";"";

column1: 232679450301431808;"blackjok3r#3181";"11-Oct-18 12:41 PM";"I am pretty sure the chance of a mismatch increases with more and more chains added to the cluster.";"";"";
232679450301431808;"blackjok3r#3181";"11-Oct-18 12:42 PM";"also things like ondemand chains
column2: and PoS chains with blocktimes that can vary a lot
column3: might introduce other points of failure
column4: and we need to test that thourghly aswell still.";"";"";
